Prisoner's Defence. I met her the night before, and asked her to lend me a shawl - she said she had not one, but if I went to the prosecutrix I might borrow one of her: I had the misfortune to lose it.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined One Month .

723.
JOHN FOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 6 shillings and 3 sixpences , the monies of
John Jones
.

ELIZABETH JONES
. I am the wife of John Jones - we live in Maiden-lane
. On the 4th of February I went into the shop to snuff the candle, and found the prisoner under the counter; he rose up, and I caught hold of his collar: I found the till drawn half way out, and the bowl in which the silver had been in the till, laying by his side on the ground; I had seen it safe when he came in at half-past seven - he asked for a pint of small beer - I said I would rather not serve him; he asked again, and then I said I would draw it for him if he would go out again directly - he put me down a sixpence, and then I saw the money was all safe in my till - there was six shillings and three sixpences; he then had a pennyworth of bread, and four pennyworth of meat, which came to the whole of his sixpence - he was at this time sitting on a form in the shop.

JAMES GROOM
. Mrs. Jones's girl came to my house, and asked me to step in - I went in and found the prisoner there; Mrs. Jones had him by the collar - she said, "He has taken out my till, and got out my money" - he said,"I have no money but four shillings of my own about me."

BENJAMIN PARRETT
. I took the prisoner - he produced 7s. 6d. and one halfpenny, which he said was his own money.

JOHN HUTT
. I am the watch-house keeper - I produce these six shillings and three sixpences, which I received from Parrett.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to the shop - I asked for a pint of beer, which I got; I then asked if she had any cooked meat - she said, "No, but here are some saveloys;" I said, "Just warm one," which she did - I then had a penny loaf, and gave some persons who were in the shop part of the beer: I then knocked at the room door - Mrs. Jones came out and said, "What do you want here?" - I said I wanted another pint of beer, and that I had called for it twice, and that she had not heard me; she then asked the two persons in the shop if I had - they said they were asleep, and had not heard me: she then went to the counter, and said, "My till is out, and I have lost four or five shillings I know" - I said,
"I have six shillings and three sixpences of my own money."
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

724.
NATHANIEL DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of January , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-chain, value 10s., and 1 seal, value 6s. , the goods of
John Ward
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 31.
Transported for Seven Years .

725.
WILLIAM CLARK
,
EDWARD WAGHORN
, and
THOMAS FOWLER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of January , 1 book, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Batemen
.

THOMAS BATEMAN. I am a bookseller , and live in Goodge-street, Tottenham-court-road
. I lost a book on the 26th of January, but did not miss it till the officers told me of it; it had been inside my window, among some others, for several weeks; I am not certain when I had seen it, but I know it by the label.

WILLIAM JORDAN
. I am an officer. I saw the three prisoners together, in Leather-lane, that Saturday afternoon, about two o'clock; I watched them through several streets, to Gray's Inn-lane, where I met Cadby and Colton - we all followed them for five or six miles, through Camden-town and other places; when they got to Goodge-street, I saw Fowler take this book - the other two were close at his elbow; I told Colton and Cadby, who immediately ran across, and before I crossed they had got the three prisoners into a shop.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I was with Jordan, and followed the prisoners through a number of streets; I saw Fowler take the book, and the other two were close to him; I ran over and took Clark and Fowler into a linen-draper's shop.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I was following the prisoners - I saw Fowler take the book, and give it to Waghorn, who ran off with it, at the end of Goodge-street - I pursued and took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
CLARK'S Defence. I was looking for a situation - I saw Fowler, and asked if he knew whether it had gone five o'clock; before he could speak, the officers came, and pushed us into a shop.

CLARK -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

WAGHORN -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

FOWLER -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

726.
JOHN ABRAHAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of February , 9 seal-skins, value 27s. , the goods of
Solomon Phillips
.

SOLOMON PHILLIPS. I am a seal-skin manufacturer , and live in Fishmonger-alley, Borough, my factory is in Redcross-yard, Borough
. On Friday, the 1st of February, I counted my seal-skins, and had seventy - I went home, and did not return till the Sunday morning - I then missed nine skins, but I had before heard that some were missing; I have seen three of them since, which I know to be mine, from the marks on them - each man puts his own particular mark upon his skins.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was not the prisoner your servant? A. Yes, and up to this time he had a good character - I will take him again.

MICHAEL HUGHES
. I am a watchman. On the morning of the 2d of February, I was in Paternoster-row, Spitalfields, and saw the prisoner with a bundle under his arm; I asked what he had got; he said his work, which he had brought from the Borough, and that he was going to take it to a house in Lamb-street, next door to a dry-salters; I followed him, and as he did not seem to go into any house, I asked him again, where he was going; he said, "Stop, I will tell you - the skins are my father's;" I took hold of them, and he ran away - I pursued, and took him.

THOMAS HART
. I was beadle of the night. On the morning of the 2d of February, the prisoner was brought into the watch-house with these skins, which he said were his father's.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

727.
THOMAS FITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of January , 12 ozs. weight of tobacco, value 3s. , the goods of
William Henry Isaac
.

WILLIAM HENRY ISAAC. I am a tobacconist , and live in Upper York-street. On the 17th of January, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, I received information from some little girls, and pursued the prisoner; I saw him opposite the Yorkshire Stingo public-house, with two or three other persons; I seized him, put my hand to his pocket, and felt this parcel of tobacco; he begged I would not give him in charge; but wished me to go with him to Stingo-lane, and he would hand me over another parcel of tobacco, which he had given to another boy; I refused, but took him into a shop; he gave me the name of the other boy, which was Collier - he wished to go away, and offered to leave his coat; I left him in the shop, and went with my brother to Stingo-lane, but could find no such person; when I returned, he told the officers the name of Collier, and they took him; he said the prisoner had thrown away one packet of tobacco; when I first took him he said he took it from my window, and begged I would not give him in charge - they are packets of Dutch C'naster, and I have brought another to shew the similarity; I had three packets of this sort, and all in blue papers; I have not opened them, but they feel like tobacco - I had them from a very respectable house; I have not any dummies in my shop.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you any mark of your own on this parcel, before it was taken? A. No; I did not say I would not hurt him, if he would tell me where any of the other boys lived; nor anything of the kind; I will not swear that this parcel was not mixed with others before I marked it - I marked it in my shop, before it went to the office - it was then laying on my shop-counter - I can only swear I had packets similar to this, and lost packets similar to this.

RICHARD HARTLEY WALL
. I was not the officer who was sent for, but I received this tobacco from Buckbridge, who is now dangerously ill.
Cross-examined. Q. Before you got it, where had it been kept? A. In the cupboard at the office.
GUILTY - Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

728.
JAMES CAMP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February , 1 pair of breeches, value 10s. , the goods of
James West
.

JAMES WEST. I live at Enfield, and am servant to Mr. Cracknold. I had a box of clothes in a shed, in his orchard - I kept the key of it; I put the things into it about noon, on the Thursday, while I was working in the garden. On Saturday, the 9th of February, the prisoner, whom I knew, came to me, and asked if I had lost anything; I said No; he said, "I think you have, look in your box, and see if you have lost any clothes;" I went to look, and the box was gone: he then said he had found the box open, in a ditch, as he was coming to work; there was a pair of black breeches and a waistcoat in it; I said, "There was a pair of corded breeches in it, have you seen them?" he said No, he had not; I have since seen a pair of corded breeches, which I believe are mine - I had bought them the week before of Mrs. Parker, and had only worn them on the Sunday.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is Mrs. Parker here? A. Her man is; I found these breeches at Mr. King's.

JAMES STRINGER
. I am shopman to Mrs. Parker; I sold a pair of breeches to the prosecutor - these are like them; I do not see any difference, but I cannot swear to them.
Cross-examined. Q. You have a great many more of the same sort? A. Yes; I never sold any to the prisoner but Mrs. Parker might.

THOMAS SIMKINS
. The prosecutor lodges with me; I saw him have a pair of breeches on like these, which he said he bought of Mrs. Parker, and he should not wear them again till Easter.

JAMES KING
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 11th of February these breeches were pawned with me - I cannot say by whom.

JOHN MEAD
. I am a constable of Enfield. I was before the Magistrate when the prisoner was examined; what he said was taken down - he had it read to him, and made his mark; this is Magistrate's signature - (read.)

The said J. Camp, the prisoner, being called on by me for what he has to say, and cautioned by me not to say any thing to his own injury, saith, "I did take the box with the clothes out of the tool house; what the first witness has said is true, I did pawn the breeches with Mr. King for 5s., and threw the duplicate in the fields: nobody induced me to tell this; I wished to make it up with the prosecutor."
Prisoner. Mr. Wilson, the constable, told me to say so.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

729.
ELIZABETH COATES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 1 bed, value 50s.; 1 bolster, value 5s.; 2 pillows, value 8s.; 3 blankets, value 10s; 1 pair of sheets; value 4s.; 1 tea-kettle value 3s., and 2 tables, value 5s. the goods of
Ann Simons
.

ANN SIMONS. The prisoner lodged with me. On the 4th of February she took out my table - she left her children in the room, and when she came back she was taken; I know the whole of these things to be mine; they are part of the furniture which I had let her with the room.

HENRY HAINES
. I bought two tables of the prisoner; one on Saturday evening, the 2d of February, at seven o'clock; and the other a little after eight o'clock, on the 4th.
Cross-examined by MR. J. ALLEY. Q. What did you give for the two tables? A. Four and sixpence, which is above the value; but I took compassion on her.

ANN LOOSEMORE
. I bought the duplicate of a bed of the prisoner; she said it was a new tick, and a very good one. I sent for the bed; she called upon me again, to know if I could let her have any more, and I said, "Is that a new tick?" she looked round, and said, "Dear me, how came it so dirty?" She then said her aunt had pawned it; and I told her, if she would return the 2s. which I had given her, she might have it again; I afterwards sold it.

JOHN NORRIS
. I was sent for to Mrs. Simmons; I found the prisoner crying - she told me where she had sold the tables - I went and got them - she said she had sold the duplicates of the other things - she is married and I believe has three children.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Fourteen Days .

730.
THOMAS CALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of December , 1 carpenter's rule, value 2s. , the goods of
Henry Wright
.
HENRY WRIGHT. I am a carpenter . I lent this rule on the 17th of December - I know it to be mine.

ABRAHAM STANNARD
. Wright lent me this rule on the 17th of December, and I was using it on the latter part of that day, at a house in Brunswick-street, Hackney-road
; Wright came next morning to ask me for it, and it was gone - the prisoner was at work at the same building, but I had not lent to him.

WILLIAM BRIGG
. I live with Mr. Attenborough, pawnbroker. I took in this rule on the 17th of December, in the name of Henry Ward; but I cannot say of whom - this is the duplicate which I gave for it.

JAMES ORFORD
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 28th of January - I searched him and found two duplicates in his fob of two rules - one was for this rule which Wright has sworn to.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the rule of my partner, a mason named Poole; he ran away from the work the Monday before Christmas-day - I continued to work there till I was taken.

ABRAHAM STANNARD
re-examined. Q. Did you know a person of the name of Poole? A. Yes; he did work there; he received some money from our master, on the Monday before Christmas-day, to go and pay for some work; he never paid for it; but went away.
NOT GUILTY .

731.
ELIZABETH BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 1 tea-kettle, value 2s. , the goods of
John Mould
.

JOHN MOULD. I keep the Green Man and Still public-house, in Coppice-row, Clerkenwell
. The prisoner came there on the 14th of February, and asked for a pennyworth of porter; said she was extremely cold, and went into the tap-room, where she remained some time; there were five persons there drinking; she had a black apron on, which she threw over the tea-kettle, and took it away; I received information, pursued, and took her in Ray-street, about fifty yards off with it.

CHARLES CAMERON
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Transported for Seven Years .

732.
THOMAS BARRETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of January , 69lbs. weight of lead, value 13s., and 1 sack, value 2s. , the goods of
Frederick Charles Burton
.

THOMAS HENRY HURT
. I work for Mr. Burton. I left his shop in Eagle-street about two o'clock on the 17th of January - he is a plumber and glazier ; before I had left I had stripped off some lead - I believe this to be part of it.
Prisoner. Q. Do you know the Cheshire Cheese public-house, in Dean-street? A. Yes - I use it every day for my breakfast and dinner.

JAMES MEDLYCOT
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner on the 17th of January, in Eagle-street, about half past six o'clock in the evening, with this lead in a sack; I asked what he had got - he said some lead, which he had brought from Penton-place, where he had been working for himself - that it was lead which he had left, and he was going to take it back to Mr. Ransom, in Bedfordbury, of whom he had bought it; I detained him, and went there; they said they knew him, but had not sold him any lead.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I am an officer. I was with Medlycot, and staid with the prisoner while he went to Ransom's; while he was gone the prisoner said to me, "I am very sorry I told him wrong - I have had the lead some time, and was going to sell it to get myself a pair of shoes."

FREDERICK CHARLES BURTON
. I am a lead-merchant. I had a quantity of lead on my premises; I have compared this with what remains, and I believe it to be the same.

The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that a man named Davenport had given him the lead to dispose of, at the Cheshire Cheese public-house, for which he promised to give him a pair of new shoes.

THOMAS RANSOM
. I am the brother of Mr. Ransom, of Bedfordbury. My brother has employed the prisoner for years, and he always had a good character.

FREDERICK CHARLES BURTON. This witness called at my house, and told my brother that if I would go to a public-house in Broad-street, previous to the hearing, he could give me information of several men who had robbed me - I went there, and saw him; he then said if I would give him a sovereign he would tell me something; I said I would not - he then said he should not tell me anything.
THOMAS RANSOM. I did tell him I could give him some information; but it was only what I derived from the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Confined Two Months .

733.
THOMAS HOPKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of January , 1 sovereign, 2 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 2 sixpences, the goods of
Peter Wade
, from his person .

PETER WADE. On the 20th of January I was in Whitechapel
, about two o'clock in the morning, and had taken a drop too much; I was taken to the watch-house - when I got there I had one sovereign, three half-crowns, two shillings, and two sixpences; I had taken it for my wages about a quarter before twelve o'clock that night - I then went and drank, but did not pay for any thing - my master paid for what I had; I was put into a room where the prisoner and some other persons were; I lost my money in the night, and the next morning I saw some money taken from the prisoner's shoes; I was three parts drunk, and do not know what I had done before I went into the watch-house.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is your master here? A. No. I was taken near the church in Whitechapel - I believe they took me to the watch-house for safety; I had a long way to go home: I live at Stepney- my master is Mr. Cann, a hair-dresser, living in Fleet-street; I received my money at his shop, and then went with him to a public-house in Fetter-lane; I and three more drank nine or ten glasses of gin and water. In going from the public-house to Whitechapel a number of men and women spoke to me; several females came very near to me: after I left the public-house I showed my money to two of my shopmates, named Scott and Sinclair.

THOMAS SMITH
. I am beadle of Whitechapel. On Sunday morning, the 20th of January, the prisoner was brought to the watch-house, but I am not certain whether he was searched or not; while he was there I brought in the prosecutor from High-street, the worse for liquor; I do not know what he had about him, but about six o'clock the next morning he said he was very sorry, and hoped I would let him go home; I said, "Have you got every thing safe about you?" he then felt, and said he had lost a sovereign, some half-crowns, and some silver; I went into the room where the others were, and brought out the prisoner; I found a sovereign, two shillings, and two sixpences in his left waistcoat pocket, and one half-crown in each of his shoes - he said he had it from his father. I saw an apron taken out of a hat, but I do not know whose it was.

Cross-examined. Q. What did the prosecutor say he was sorry for having done? A. I was dispersing some low men and women, and he came in among them, and asked what I wanted to do; he was a good deal the worse for liquor - he had a watch when he went in, but I did not see any money.

WILLIAM HEATH
. I am a patrol of Whitechapel. I assisted in taking the prisoner to the watch-house, for rescuing a girl from a watchman, in White Lion-street; I saw him searched the next morning, and the money found - Dungate took his hat off, and found in it this apron, which was claimed by Wade; I heard the prosecutor say he had lost 1l. 10s. 6d. - I think he said a sovereign, four half-crowns, and a sixpence; I did not search the other persons who were there, as they were only put in for being disorderly, fighting, and such like, which is frequently the case in that part of the town.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you search the prisoner when he went into the watch-house? A. No - I searched the other persons who went in; and one of them had no money when he went in, but the next morning there was half a crown and a shilling found upon him.

JOHN DUNGATE
. I am an officer. I took the apron out of the prisoner's hat, and found a half-crown in each of his shoes - I did not search him when he went it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the prosecutor brought in? A. Yes; he certainly was very drunk - I was in an adjoining room; I was not in the hole with the prisoner. They have no candle nor fire.
NOT GUILTY .
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 27.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

734.
BRIDGET RYAN
and
ELIZABETH MARLOW
were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of January , 1 watch, value 20s.; 1 watch-key, value 20s.; 1 watchchain, value 1s.; and 1 watch guard, value 1s., the goods of
John King
, from his person .

JOHN KING. On the 21st of January, as I was going home, at two o'clock in the morning, I saw two men ill using the prisoner Ryan; she asked me for protection; I went with her to her own room; I went to bed, and put my watch under the pillow, and in the morning, when I was putting my stockings on, I saw her take my watch and boots and go out, I said "Give me my watch;" she said I should have it; I could not follow, as I was undressed. Marlow had burst the door open, and asked Ryan if she wanted any gin; she fetched the gin, and, in half an hour, she took the things out of the room. I took Ryan at her own room next morning; she said she was very sorry she had committed the robbery - I am sure she said "robbery." I told the Magistrate so.

JOSEPH HALL
. On the 21st of January, Marlow pawned this watch with me, about nine o'clock in the morning; she said she brought it from a friend who was at her house - the prosecutor came in that morning very tipsy.

RYAN'S Defence. I was letting a friend out; the prosecutor came and spoke to me; he went up; he said he had been with a woman before, and she had robbed him; and in the morning, he said he would thank me to go and get eight shillings on his watch, and then he got me to pawn his ring.
JOHN KING. I did not; I had plenty of silver.
MARLOW'S Defence. I saw him give her the watch to pawn, and she gave it to me to get ten shillings on it.
NOT GUILTY .

735.
GEORGE DIXON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of February , 2 cwt. of lead, value 30s., the goods of
Thomas Skelton
, and fixed to a building of his .

THOMAS SKELTON. I lost this lead from a house, which I let, in Church-lane, St. George's
; I know it was all safe on the roof on the 1st of February.

THOMAS SCOTT
. I am tenant of this house; the lead was all safe on the 1st of February, as I was on the roof: on the 2d of February it was all cut ready to be taken away - a neighbour came, about seven o'clock that evening, and said there was a man on the top of my house; I went up and found a parcel of lead, loose, on the top of the dormer; it was not rolled up, but cut off, and in about half an hour I again heard there was somebody on the house - I went up with my son, and found another piece cut off, and saw it matched, and it fitted exactly.

WILLIAM HAY
. I live at No. 64, Church-lane, two doors from Scott. On the 2d of February, I came from Hackney, and heard some lead was gone: Scott said he thought there was somebody on the house then; I went up and saw the prisoner on the roof, I followed him over the tops of the houses; he got in at a window, and was taken on the first floor of No. 5, Church-lane - it was then near eight o'clock.

OWEN SULLIVAN
. I am a watchman. I was at Scott's house, and heard an alarm; I went and took the prisoner, on the first floor of No. 5; I heard something drop from the him, which proved to be this knife.

JOHN JAMES
. I am a sailor, and lodge in Rosemary-lane, with the prisoner. On Saturday evening, the 2d of February, he left me about 6 o'clock - I know the knife produced to be his; I have often borrowed it.

WILLIAM SUMMERS
. I am an officer. The prisoner was given into my charge; I found nothing upon him - I have fitted the lead; it corresponded exactly with the dormer.
Prisoner's Defence. I had no money to pay for a lodging and went there to sleep.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

736.
SAMUEL PHILLIPS, alias ABRAHAM ABRAHAMS
, and
CHARLES alias COLLEY BENJAMIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 2 sovereigns and one 5l. Bank note, the property of
Edmund Watling
, their master; against the Statute .
The prisoners having been convicted at Clerkenwell of obtaining the property in question by conspiracy, the case was not proceeded with.
NOT GUILTY .

623.
CHARLES ROSSER
was indicted for
feloniously receiving 2 bars of iron, value 5s. 6d., the goods of our Lord
the King
, knowing the same to have been stolen .
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE WALKER
. I am a carpenter employed by the Surveyor of Hyde-park
. Part of the iron railing was taken away; I found some of it at Mr. Fox's, of Knightsbridge, about one o'clock on the 23d of January.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Is there anything particular about that railing? A, I know it by putting it up.

JAMES SHEDDEN
. I am surveyor of Hyde-park. I went to Fox's house, on the 24th of January, and found these two iron bars, which were taken from the outlet at Hyde-park; and in consequence of what passed, I went to the prisoner's house, in North-street, Knightsbridge - he was out; I sent an officer, who brought him in about five minutes; I asked him how he became possessed of the iron, which was at Fox's; he hesitated, and said he bought them honestly; I asked where, he said of two boys; I said, "Did you know them;" he hesitated, and then said "I don't know;" his wife said "Yes, Rosser, you do know; you had them from young Griffiths;" he said "Yes it was him and another person he did not know - I asked where Griffith's lived; he made no answer, but his wife said, "Just by, in Cross-street, over a stable:" we went in search, but could not find him; I asked the prisoner what he gave for it; he said 1d. for 3lbs., which would be 1s. 10 1/2d. - they are worth 17s. 4d.
Cross-examined. Q. As old iron, would it be worth more than he gave? A. It was not old iron; 17s. 4d. is the new price; he went with me to look for Griffiths - the prisoner keeps an old iron shop.

SAMUEL FOX
. I bought these two bars of iron of the prisoner the day before they were found - they are wrought iron.
Cross-examined. Q. As old iron, is one more valuablethan another? A. Yes: I bought them as old iron - they stood openly in his yard.
COURT. Q. Did you think them old iron? A. I bought them as such; I asked him no questions; I had known him living there ten years, and bearing a good character for anything I knew.

THOMAS AMSDEN
. I am a patrol of Bow-street. I found the bars in the shop.

GEORGE WALKER
. I have no particular mark on them; they are cut off very rough, and are the same size and dimensious; I had fixed them up, and two were pulled down.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

738.
WILLIAM BARNARD
was indicted for
embezzlement .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Twelve Months .

739.
EDWARD WELCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of December , 1 piece of wood, called quartering, value 2s. , the goods of our Lord
the King
.

SECOND COUNT, of the Hon.
William Sturges Bourne
,
William Dacres Adams
, Esq. , and
Henry Dawkins
, Esq.
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

PETER COOKE BARRAND
. I am a carpenter, and live at the Castle, in Moor's-yard
. About 7 o'clock in the morning, about two months ago, there was some paling there; I saw the prisoner there; he pulled a piece of quartering out of the ground, and walked away with it on his shoulder; I followed him into Vere-street, and then said, "That is the way the wood goes from Moor's-yard:" he turned round and said, "I may as well take it away as another, my master put it up." I said he did not authorize you to take it away - I saw him take it into a house in Vine-street. I then gave information.

WILLIAM OXLEY
. I am a constable. I was sent for, and took the prisoner at a public-house - I got this piece of timber from Andrews.

WILLIAM ANDREWS
. I bought this wood of the prisoner; I am in the employ of Mr. M'Pherson, a publican, in Chandos-street - I did not ask where he got it; I bought it for firewood: part has been burned.

JAMES GILBERT
. This wood is the property of the Commissioners of Woods and Forests; it was in Moor's-yard under my care.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that there were three other persons of his name residing in the street, and that he had not committed the robbery.
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Confined Three Months .

740.
JOHN PHILPOT
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM SHEARMAN
. I am a carpenter , and live in Little Anchor-street, Church-street, Bethnal-green; the prisoner worked for me occasionally for about three years; he was in my employ on the 14th of July , 1824; I occasionally employed him to collect money; I told him on that day to receive 1l. 16s. 6d. from Tucker - he should have brought me the money the same morning; I never saw him afterwards till he was taken, and have never received the money.

JOSEPH VERISON TUCKER
, In July, 1824, I owed Shearman 1l. 16s. 6d., which I paid to a man - I cannot say whether the prisoner is the man: here is the receipt the person gave me.
WILLIAM SHEARMAN. When I took the prisoner he said, voluntarily, that he had spent Tucker's money, and I ought to have had it.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Confined Three Months .

741.
SAMUEL WARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of November , 1 bushel of mixed corn, called horse-corn, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Deborah Dixon
, widow .
MR. COOPER conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS GREENFIELD
. I am coachman to Mrs. Deborah Dixon, widow; I drove the Henley coach for her from there to London. On the 3d of November, I stopped with the coach at some private stables at Hounslow
, which she rents of Stuckbury; before I changed horses I saw the prisoner at the back of the stable; I got off my coach, and went round to the back stable - I had seen the prisoner there before, and desired him not to remain there - it is a private yard: we have two rest-horses and a corn-bin in the back stable; I saw the prisoner go to the bin, and fill a bag, which he hid under the dunghill - he did not see me; I went up, and said, "Mr. Ward, what have you got there?" he said, "D - n it, here is a great rat;" he took up a brick, and ran round the stable; I went after him, but he crossed the field, and ran away; I went to the dung-heap, and found this corn in the bag - it is called horse-corn; all the corn there belongs to Mrs. Dixon - here is nearly a bushel of it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was never in the stable; I found it under the granary, and threw it on the ground.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

742.
JEREMIAH DONOVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of January , 1 cloak, value 30s. , the goods of
Thomas Larkman
.

THOMAS LARKMAN. I keep the Wheatsheaf public-house, Holywell-street, Strand
. On the 18th of January this cloak hung in my club-room; I went up about seven o'clock, and saw the prisoner and two young men - the young men went away soon after, but the prisoner seemed loath to go; I said he must go; he went out, but soon returned, and staid in the tap-room; I went out, and returned in ten minutes - he was then gone; I went up stairs, and missed my cloak; I afterwards apprehended him; Berkley gave me the duplicate.

MARIA BERKLEY
. I saw the prisoner a few days after this; he gave me the duplicate of a cloak - I gave it up.

JAMES TAGUS SHOOT
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Fetter-lane. On the 19th of January this cloak was pawned by a young woman, not Berkley, in the name of Jesse Moriencourt.

HENRY MORGAN
. I am an officer. I took Moriencourt, and she took me to the pawnbroker's where I found the cloak - she was bound over, but is not here; I then took Berkley.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was at his house, and went out to look for Mr. Grantham, and then went home; I afterwards heard of the robbery, and asked Larkman if he suspected me, why he did not give me in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Three Months .

743.
JOHN ROACH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of January , 1 pair of scales, value 20s.; 1 till, value 2s., and 10 shillings , the property of
John Manning
.

HARRIET MANNING
. I am the wife of John Manning, a baker , of New-street, Covent-garden
. On the 16th of January I was at home, and saw the prisoner lurking about the window, from eight to nine o'clock; and about eleven o'clock at night I saw a boy leaving the shop, and believe it to be the prisoner; I then missed a pair of scales off my counter; and my till, containing about 10s.; I was in the parlour - there was nobody in the shop; I gave an alarm, and he was pursued; I saw the prisoner in custody next day.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You only saw the back of the boy who left your shop? A. No, not then.
COURT. Q. You had seen the face of the boy when he was lurking about? A. Yes; that was the prisoner, and, I believe he is the boy who ran out.

ANN MITCHELL
. I am servant to Mr. Manning. On the 16th of January, just before eleven o'clock at night, the prisoner came into the shop, and asked me two or three times to let him have three penny biscuits for 1d.; I would not; he went out; I saw him lurking about the window; I went into the parlour, and soon after the scales were gone; I ran out, but could not see him - I believe him to be the boy; the scales are not found - the till was safe when I was in the shop, which was three minutes before.
Cross-examined. Q. Will you swear you saw him in the shop after he came for the biscuits? A. No.

JOHN GIMBER
. I am a writer. I was passing the prosecutor's house, about eleven o'clock, and a person passed me, with a box in his hand - he appeared much like the prisoner; I could not see his face; I described him to the officer - I believe him to be the boy - his dress was the same when he was taken.

JOHN GROOM
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, between two and three o'clock on the 17th, from Mrs. Manning's description.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

744.
GEORGE SALES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of January , 2 1/2lbs. of mutton, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Joshua Walden
.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a grocer, and live in Golden-lane. On the 12th of January, about twelve o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner by Walden's house, which is next door to me - he went up to the door, took the mutton off the stand, and threw it away a few yards off; I ran and secured him five yards off, on the other side of the way.

JOSEPH WALDEN
. I am a butcher , and live two doors from Williams. I was at my door; the prisoner came, and took a neck of mutton - it was thrown into the road; a friend took it up.

ALEXANDER MOORE
. The prisoner was given into my charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I was rather intoxicated; I took the meat, and threw it down, not with any felonious intention; I offered to pay for it when they took me - I did not move from the place.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

745.
JOHN MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of January , 1 half-sovereign, the money of
John Cohen
, his master .

JOHN COHEN. I am a musician , and live in Leman-street, Goodman's-fields
; the prisoner was about four weeks in my employ. On the 20th of January I missed a sovereign, and on the 25th some money was marked; the prisoner behaved very well before this - the half-sovereign was taken on the 26th - he behaved very honest before.

JOHN BRENDLING
. I am landlord of the house where Cohen lives. I marked eleven sovereigns and a half-sovereign for him; he put them into a bag, and gave them to his wife; the prisoner was charged with taking a half-sovereign, and gave it up to me; here it is - it is the one I marked.

MARY COHEN
. On Saturday Brendling marked some sovereigns, in a bag, which I put into a box, in my bed-room, and locked it; on Sunday morning my husband told me half a sovereign was missing.

JAMES LEE
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 26th; I made him no promise; I said, "Where is the half-sovereign?" he said he had taken it out of the box, and given it to Brendling before I got there.
GUILTY. Aged 14.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

746.
JOHN BOYLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th February , 3 rasps, value 6s.; 9 copper rivets, value 2d.; 2 hammers, value 1s. 6d.; 1 screw, value 1d.; 1 rivet set, value 1d., and 1 button set, value 1d. , the goods of
John Braithwaite
, his master.

CHARLES LEE
. I am shopman to Mr. Braithwaite, a brazier , of New-road, Surrey-square. The prisoner was eight or nine years in his employ - I went to his lodging, in Little Brook-street; I sent for an officer, who found these tools there - they are what we work with; the men never take the tools home, without leave - if he had asked leave he might have taken them; some men work at home, but the prisoner did not - he has only a small room.

WILLIAM HEATH
. I am an officer. I found the tools at the prisoner's lodging; he said part of them were his own, and part he had borrowed.

JOHN BRAITHWAITE
. The prisoner worked for me - here are several new files, which have never been used - men at times do jobs for themselves.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been in business with another man, but it did not answer, and we divided our tools- I sold them as I could, and lent some; they are common tools.
NOT GUILTY .

747.
JOHN WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 1 bed, value 5s. 6d.; 1 pillow, value 5s.; 2 blankets, value 5s., and 1 counterpane, value 5s. , the goods of
Joseph Pynn
.

JOSEPH PYNN. I am a ship-carpenter - the prisoner is a labourer in the coal trade . On the 20th of February I delivered these articles to him, in Shakspeare's-walk, Shadwell
, to take on board the John and Mary, on the other side the river, and deliver them to Blenkinsey, the mate; I have not seen them since.

ROBERT BLENKINSEY
. I was on board the John and Mary, on the 20th of February. I have known the prisoner two or three years; he never brought these articles to me.

JAMES WAYLING
. I am an officer; took the prisoner last Friday, and he said it was all settled, but afterwards said he sold the things in Rosemary-lane, which he should not have done if he had not been in liquor.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Two Months .

748.
CHARLES TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February , 1 piece of mahogany, value 5s.; 1 cap, value 2s.; 1 plane, value 2s.; 1 oil-stone, value 1s.; 1 chisel, value 6d.; 1 guage, value 6d.; 1 hammer, value 1s., and 1 pair of saw-handles, value 1s. , the goods of
Richard Hewett
.
RICHARD HEWETT. I am a cabinet-maker , and live in King-street, Hammersmith. The prisoner worked for me; I lost these tools at different times.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Does he not work at home? A. Yes, I have borrowed tools of him; they are at my place now - some of them have been lost - the wood was found on him, in the shop.

DAVID DAVIE
. I am an officer. I went with Hewett to the prisoner's lodging, and found these tools.(Property produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .

749.
JAMES SHEA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 coat, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s. 1 pair of trousers, value 5s.; 1 shirt, value 1s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2d. , the goods of
John Bell
.

JANE BELL
. I am the daughter of John Bell, shipwright , of Hermitage-street, Wapping
. On the 16th of February, about three o'clock in the afternoon, when my father was out, the prisoner came and asked if Mr. Bell lived there; I said Yes; he said he came from the ship for these articles; my father was working on board the Atlas; he said he came from Mr. Bell for them, as he was going out with the captain; I delivered these clothes to him, believing that he came from my father.

JOHN BELL
. I know nothing of the prisoner, and never sent him for any thing; I have not found my clothes.

JAMES JEFFREY
. I called at the prisoner's house - his brother came and gave himself up; I sent for the witness, who said he was not the man; I said if the prisoner did not come I should come and take him; he came, and she said he was the man.
The Prisoner called -

JULIA CALNAN
. I live at No. 2, George-street, Foley-place, Regent's-park. Last Saturday week I was at the prisoner's father's apartment from half-past one o'clock till half-past four - his father is my brother; I went there in consequence of a letter I had from Ireland - the prisoner was there; I believe his brother knew Mr. Bell; the prisoner was not sitting with his mother and me - his brother is older than him.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months .

750.
JAMES NEEDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 3 bushels of potatoes, value 8s., and 1 sack, value 1s. , the goods of
William Hobbs
.

WILLIAM HOBBS. I am a farmer , and live at Enfield
. The prisoner was my carter ; on the 19th of February I sent him, and some more men, to drive some potatoes home from the field: I ordered the men to load ten sacks in each cart, and no more - I went home and told my sister to mind what came in - I then went to market.

GEORGE ROBINSON
. I am in Hobb's employ; he ordered me to put ten sacks into each cart; the prisoner drove one cart: I saw that every cart was loaded with ten sacks- none of them had more nor less, I am certain; he had to take them to the yard, which is three-quarters of a mile from the field.

REBECCA HOBBS
. I am the prosecutor's sister: he told me to watch every cart; the prisoner came into the yard several times - I went out each time to see him unload, and one time he brought nine full sacks and one empty - I said nothing to him, but told my brother when he came home.

THOMAS COREHAM
. I am in Mr. Hobb's employ; he told me to assist in unloading the potatoes; the prisoner came with one load of nine sacks full and one empty - all the other loads were ten full sacks; I said nothing to him about it.

JOHN WILSON
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner; he said there was not a sack lost - that he shot a few potatoes over a gate, but who had them he did not know.
GUILTY. Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

751. JOHN PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Blizard
.

JAMES GIBBS
. I am a butcher, and live at Hollywell-lane. On the 16th of February, about half-past five o'clock, I saw a boy go and take a pair of shoes from Mr. Blizard's shop; I ran out and pursued the prisoner and another - I caught the prisoner in Shoreditch, and saw the shoes close by him; I cannot swear he took them.
THOMAS BLIZARD. These are my shoes - I know nothing of the prisoner.

SAMUEL STUDD
. I heard a cry of Stop thief! ran out, and saw the prisoner drop these shoes - I am sure he is the boy.
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Whipped and Discharged.

752.
DAVID DAVIS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 seal, value 5s.; 1 key, value 3s., and 1 ring, value 2s., the goods of
Michael Dibley
, knowing the same to be stolen .

The evidence was the same in this case as that produced on the trial of Morris and others, page 321, except that the witness, Kett, deposed to the prisoner being in the house at the time of the robbery, and sitting on the same bench with Morris, who was seen to give him the watch.
NOT GUILTY .

753.
JOHN MAYO
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of December , 2 sheets, value 7s., and 1 pillow, value 5s. , the goods of
George Jones
.

ANN JONES
. I am the wife of George Jones, a shoemaker . I let the prisoner a bed in November last - I lost the sheets and pillow, and have not found them; nobody else lodged in the house except a very respectable school-master - the prisoner went out early in the morning on the 1st of December: and I did not see him again till the other day when I met him at Bayswater, and he offered to pay me for them at so much a week - I gave charge of him.
Prisoner. I said I would give anything to her, as I was going to a situation.
GUILTY . Aged 49.
Confined Six Months .

654.
SARAH LEWIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of January , 1 pair of shoes, value 5s., and 1 tablecloth, value 5s. , the goods of
Ambrose Bradley
.

AMBROSE BRADLEY. I am a pawnbroker . The prisoner occasionally charred at my house, and was there from the 12th to the 26th of January, washing a quantity of goods - she absconded. I had her apprehended, and duplicates of the articles were found on her.

EDWARD RUBERY
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Osborne-street, Whitechapel. I have a table-cloth, and a pair of shoes, pawned by Green, in her own name.

ANN GREEN
. I pawned these things for the prisoner; I believed them to be her own.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOSHUA CLEMENTS
. I am an officer. I found the duplicates of these, and other things on the prisoner; she said she meant to return them.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined Three Months .

755.
MICHAEL MORAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th February , 1 opera-glass, value 2l., the goods of
James Ils Chaffin
, from his person .

JAMES ILES CHAFFIN. On the 25th of February I was returning with a friend from Drury-lane Theatre - I was under the Piazza in Covent-garden, near James-street
, and had an opera-glass in my right-hand coat pocket (I do not reside in town) - I felt my pocket lighter; an officer came and told me I had been robbed, and produced it. I had not seen the prisoner.

JOHN BOSTON
. I am a watchman, in the employ of the Commissioners of Woods and Forests. I was returning home, and saw the prisoner and another go up to this gentleman; the prisoner took the glass out of his pocket - I seized them both, but was obliged to let the other go, as there were a number of boys and girls round; I took the glass from him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. He has a spite against me.
GUILTY . Aged 11.
Transported for Seven Years .
The prisoner was convicted of felony at the Westminster Sessions, in July, and sentenced to two months' imprisonment and Whipped.

756.
THOMAS KERSHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of February , 1 half-crown, and 1 shilling , the monies of
John Jones
.

CLARA GREER
. I am servant to John Jones, a tobacconist . I saw the prisoner at our shop three weeks ago, and served him with some tobacco, which came to seven farthings - he gave me a sovereign; I went into the parlour for change - my mistress came into the shop, and gave it to him: he then said he wanted 10s. worth of halfpence - she said she had not got it; he gave the silver back, and said it was of no use without, and paid for the tobacco in halfpence; my mistress put the silver on the counter, and when he was gone we missed 3s. On the 23d he came again for half an ounce of tobacco, and again gave me a sovereign; I went in and told my mistress I thought he was the man who took the 3s.; she then gave me six half-crowns and five shillings, which I took to him; he said,"It is of no use unless you can give me 10s. in halfpence- I told you so," but he had not; he put the silver back into my hand, and was putting his hand into his waistcoat pocket, for money to pay for his tobacco; I looked at the silver, and missed a half-crown; I said, "You have got half a crown" - he said he had not; my master came out of the room, and laid hold of him - he dropped the half-crown, and a shilling which I had not missed.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you returned his sovereign? A. It laid at the end of the counter: he had not taken it up when I accused him of it; he had not attempted to take it up.

JOHN JONES
. I keep this shop. The prisoner came and the girl came in, and said he was the man who had been before; I saw six half-crowns and five shillings given to her, which she went and gave him; he said, "I want 10s. in halfpence;" she said we had none - he put back the silver; she accused him of keeping the half-crown: I came out, and took him; he dropped the half-crown and shilling - I detained him.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you near enough to hear what he said? A. Yes - I believe the sovereign was on the counter, but cannot say.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. I was sent for, and found on the prisoner a sovereign, two shillings, and three pence.
Prisoner's Defence. I asked for 10s. worth of copper.
GUILTY . Aged 54.
Confined Six Months .

757.
JOHN HERRING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of February , 1 shawl, value 10s.; 4 dead ducks, value 3s.; 1 bonnet, value 10s., 1 half-sovereign, and 23 shillings , the property of
James Steward
.

ELLEN STEWARD
. I am the wife of James Steward - we live in a small stable, in Stratton-mews, Bloomsbury
. On Friday night I was at home - my husband was in the country; a little girl slept with me, and her brother in the same room; I went to bed about eleven o'clock - all was fastened then. I awoke, and saw the window open - it is one story high; there are carts in the yard: I think a person could get up without a ladder. The girl awoke me, saying the window was open, and there was a thief in the room; I looked up, and saw the prisoner in his shirt-sleeves, and his black waistcoat - he blew out the rushlight, took off the counterpane, and covered his face, and ran down stairs - we called Murder! and Thieves! I got up, and went to his place, where his wife lays in; he lives next door to us - we knew him well; he was not there: the shawl and ducks were found behind a cart in the mews, with his jacket.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you speak to the man? A. No, I was afraid. I never accused any body else of it; I know Flood - he slept with the prisoner- I did not accuse him of it, but said he must have puthim up to get into the room. My property was all safe when I went to bed.

JAMES RUTH
. I am thirteen years old, and slept in the room; I was awake, and saw the prisoner come to the drawers - I am certain of him; I knew him before: I called out; Mrs. Steward was awake - he put out the rushlight, which stood on the table, close to the bed. I saw him take the money from the drawers.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you not rather frightened? A. Yes. I did not tell the Magistrate he was the man, but I am sure he is.

GEORGE PRATT
. I am a watchman. At a quarter to two o'clock in the morning, I heard a rattle spring, and ran to the spot; I found this shawl, two pairs of wild fowls, and the prisoner's jacket behind a cart in the mews.

ELLEN STEWARD
. I know this to be the prisoner's jacket - I am certain of it; I saw him with it on when he got his beer for supper.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

758.
WILLIAM HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of February , 1 yard of toilinett, value 3s. , the goods of
James Hollywell
.

WILLIAM EDWARDS
. I am a constable, and live in Eight Feathers-court - the prosecutor's shop is in Holywell-street
. On the 22d of February, at eight o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner and another person there; I passed them, and heard them say, "It is all right, go it;" I watched: they waited some time, and crossed - I saw the prisoner go in at the door, and take this piece of toilinett; I crossed over, and seized him with it - he struck me a violent blow; my hat and his own fell off - he ran; I pursued him into Angel-inn-yard, and lost sight of him there, as he got under the coaches; I had his hat - he asked me for it when he was taken, and I gave it to him.

JAMES HOLLYWELL
. I keep this shop - this toilinett is mine.

JAMES STACK
. I was standing at my shop door, and saw Edwards seize the prisoner; I am certain he is the man.
The prisoner pleaded intoxication, and ignorance of the offence.

WILLIAM EDWARDS
. He was sober; he could run as fast as me.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

759.
ANN EAST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 1 coat, value 20s., and 6 yards of printed cotton, value 5s. the goods of
Francis Tracey
.

MARTHA TRACEY
. I am the wife of Francis Tracey; we live in King's-road, Chelsea
. I take in washing - the prisoner lodged with us, with a man who took the room. I missed this property on the 14th of February, between ten and eleven o'clock; there was nobody in the house but her - my husband told them to leave next day, and they did so - I have not found my things; I was in my kitchen very ill, and saw the prisoner go out with something brown in her apron, between ten and eleven o'clock; I thought it was like my husband's coat - I found that the key of her room opened my parlour - nobody else was in the house but an independant old gentleman.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. She left because you gave her warning? A. Yes. I missed the coat at seven o'clock in the evening - I did not suspect it was gone, as I had the key - it was half under her apron; my daughter was in the kitchen with me, and said it looked like her father's coat - my husband missed it at one o'clock, but said nothing to me about it - I cannot say how many people came to the house that day - I told the prisoner of it at night; she said she had not been out all day.

MARTHA TRACEY
. I am ten years old. I saw the prisoner go out on Thursday with a bundle under her apron - I saw something like my father's coat - our parlour door is kept locked, and the street door is kept shut.

Cross-examined. Q. Where were you? A. In the kitchen with my mother; I did not tell her of it, for she saw it herself. My father came home between two and three o'clock - he went to lay down, and the cotton and coat were missed.
COURT. Q. Did you then say you thought you saw her take it out? A. No.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not out all day.
NOT GUILTY .

760.
WILLIAM CHELTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of December , 7 cloaks, value 14l. the goods of
William Waldegrave Packer
.
WILLIAM WALDEGRAVE PACKER. I am an undertaker , and live in Whitechapel-road. On the 12th of December, I had a funeral of Mr. James Bates.

HANNAH PACKER
. I am the prosecutor's wife. This funeral was performed on the 12th of December, about four o'clock in the afternoon - the corpse laid in our shop, and was to be buried about a quarter of a mile from our house; the prisoner came the day after the corpse came - he merely looked at it - appeared to shed tears over it, and he agreed with a man named Bone, who came with him, as to the orders he had given for the interment - Bone has not been seen since; Bone ordered ten cloaks in the prisoner's presence - he said thirty persons would come, but only ten would follow as mourners, and my husband was to prepare the cloaks; the prisoner came again next day, but only stood on the step, while the other man talked to me a little. On the day of the funeral, it had gone on with only two mourners - the prisoner and Bone came soon after, and said, "We have met your husband and the corpse, on the other side of the way, and he desires you will tie two cloaks on our shoulders; but we won't wait for hatbands; and he will wait in the street for us." I did so, believing my husband had sent them - they went away with the two cloaks - the prisoner returned in about three minutes without a cloak, and said their overlooker from the docks, was coming up the road from the docks, with some more of the men, and as 7l. had been raised for the funeral, they did not like them to appear without cloaks; I was to give him what cloaks I had got on my arm, and my husband would wait for them - I gave him all I had on my arm - I thought there were six, but he says there was but five; I have only seen one since - I am sure he said he came by my husband's authority.

ROBERT HENRY BURGESS
. I am an officer. I received information on the 14th of January - I went to the Bull's head public-house, and took the prisoner there; heacknowledged to me next morning, that he had had the cloaks, but did not know what became of them, for he got tipsy, and lost them.

WILLIAM WALDEGRAVE PACKER. On the 12th of December I went on with the corpse; I met Bone and another man, who, I think, was the prisoner, with shovels in their hands; I went up to a mourner named Dawes, and said, "There are two of your men" - he said, "We cannot wait for them" - we went on and interred the corpse; when I returned, my wife enquired for the cloaks - I had sent nobody whatever to her for cloaks, or any thing - the whole story was false: the prisoner said at the office he did not know what had become of them, for some girls of the town put them on; one cloak has been returned - that was taken off Bone's bed, and brought to me by Dawes.

Prisoner's Defence. I never was there with Bone - I went with one Scroggins to see the corpse; I called at a public-house, and left about a dozen shovels there - I had met the men following the corpse; they said I might come if I liked - I said No, I would go to the house we were to meet at afterwards; I went next morning to Dawes' house - he said Bone had been to the funeral, and had not returned the cloaks.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

761.
JAMES GARRARD
and
ANDREW KEATING
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January , 26lbs. weight of Sugar, value 14s. , the goods of
William Sewell
and
Jonathan Wholey
.

EDWARD BARKER
. I am warehousemen to William Sewell and Jonathan Wholey, wholesale grocers
, of Upper Thames-street. I forwarded a hogshead of sugar to Mr. Beal, of Somers-town, on the 11th of January: it was brought from the Docks to our warehouse by Garrard, who is in the employ of a carman named Kay: I directed him to take it on to Beal's - this was about three o'clock in the afternoon; I examined the marks on it, and took the weight from the dock note - I knew nothing of Keating.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not examine it? A. I took the marks of it down as it was in the cart.

WILLIAM BOOTH
. I am a chemist. Between five and six o'clock on the 11th of January; I was going along Battle Bridge-road - it snowed; I met the prisoners there- they could not get on with the waggon; I and some others assisted them - Keating got into the waggon between two hogsheads, which were in it: they got as far as Weston-street, and there they staid some time; we found fault with Garrard for using his horses so badly, - I then walked round the waggon, and Keating jumped out - thinking something was wrong, I pursued and took him; he said, "Pray let me go," and asked for his hat.
Prisoner KEATING. Q. Did I not ask you where Garrard was? A. No.

MILLIAM LUMLEY
. I live in Cottage-place, City-road. I saw the waggon - Booth was talking to Garrard about whipping his horses so much; I caught hold of the horses head, and then Booth went back, and was talking under a light to a man who I could not see; Garrard then came up to me, used very bad language, and said, "What, did you never see a waggon with two horses before:" I then thought I saw something move in the waggon under the matting - I touched it with my umbrella, and Keating jumped out; we caught him, and he was taken to the watch-house: Beal came up and said, "This is my sugar, and was coming to my house" - the hogsheads were then taken to his house, and it was found 26 lbs. had been taken out of one - a few nails were found on Keating; he said he lived in the Commercial-road - there was a bag of sugar - I saw it at Mr. Beal's; I think I saw a man bring it from the waggon, but I cannot swear that - it was opened, and contained sugar, which Beale compared with the hogshead.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was it dark? A. Not very - there were gas-lights; I do not think it snowed at that time; I think I did see the bag taken from the cart - I may have sworn so at the office.
Prisoner KEATING. Q. Did I not tell you Garrard had told me to get up and fill the bag? A. He said as we went to the watch-house, that the carman asked him to come and get a little sugar.

THOMAS BEAL
. I am a grocer, and live in Skinner-street, St. Pancras. I expected two hogsheads of sugar on the 11th of January, from the prosecutors - one came in the morning; about seven o'clock I had information - I went to Brewer-street, and saw Booth bringing Keating back; I went up to the waggon, and between two hogsheads of sugar, I found a bag of sugar, and some was coming out of the hogshead into the bag then; the tin plate which covered the sample-hole, was knocked off, and twisted round - it hung by one nail; the waggon was brought to my house, and the hogshead and the bag brought in; the sugar in the bag was the same as that in the hogshead; I weighed the hogshead, and it was 26lbs. deficient.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. What is over the sample-hole? A. A piece of tin nailed on; it could not have got rubbed off - a chisel or a knife will get it off.

RICHARD COOPER
. I am a constable, and took Keating in charge. I found a few nails on him - they are not the same sort as the one left in the tin.

ROBERT TEASDALE
. I am an officer. I produce a bag of sugar, which I received from Mr. Beal; I saw the hogshead weighed - I was before the Magistrate - what the prisoners said was taken down, and read over to them; Garrard said he met Keating in Gray's Inn-lane.

THOMAS BEAL
. The nails found on Keating would nail the tin on - it is done with any kind of nails; there was a chasm in the sample-hole; I have no doubt the sugar in the bag was the same as that in the hogshead - part of it was running out when I took it.

MR. CHURCHILL. Q. If the plate had come off by accident, could they do better than put the bag to catch it? A. No; but that quantity could not have come out of itself; the proper way would be to turn the hole to the top.
KEATING'S Defence. I met Garrard in Gray's Inn-lane- he could not get on: the sugar was running out - he told me to get up and get a little out, in a bag; I picked up the nails on Galley-quay.

GARRARD'S Defence. I met him, and said I would give him a pint of beer to go with me; the tin had robbed off, by rubbing against the other hogshead - I had a bag, and told him to get in and catch it; the tin was nearly off when I had it.

JOHN HALL
. I am a publican. I have known Garrard all his life; I have worked in the docks as an operative cooper, and have frequently seen sugar wasting in the Commercial-road; from the friction of two hogsheads together; the tin, being nailed in the bulge, might very possibly rub off; I have known the tin actually worn through.
Garrard received a good character.

GARRARD -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Months .

KEATING -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

762.
GEORGE CHAMBERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 5 pieces of deal boards, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Louis England
.
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

LOUIS ENGLAND. I am a timber-merchant - the prisoner worked for me as a carpenter . On the 20th of February I lost five pieces of wood; I found them at the watch-house next day, and compared them with the boards they were cut from - they corresponded; I went to his lodging, and found some more wood, worth above 2l.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. I believe you did not suspect him before? A. No; I do not allow my men any wood; they have been cut to make a washing-tray - I know it by several marks on it - it has my foreman's name on it.

JAMES FOX
. I am watchman of the Back-road, Islington. On the 20th of February, about six o'clock in the evening; I stopped the prisoner, and found this wood in his basket.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not tell you where he had got wood? A. Yes, and said he brought it from the City road basin.

THOMAS GRAFTON
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house, and said he bought the wood at a timber-yard close to the City-road basin; I went there, and found he had not bought it there.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 46.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

763.
THOMAS CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 1 lathe, value 50s. , the goods of
James Aston
.

JAMES ASTON. I am a wood-turner , and live in St. Luke'
s. On the morning of the 12th of February I missed my lathe; I found my back window broken; I had seen the lathe safe the day before.

HUMPHRY PERRY
. I work for Aston, and was using the lathe till nine o'clock at night; I went at seven in the morning, found the window broken in, and the lathe gone.

WILLIAM ROBERTS
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Turnmill-street. On the 12th of February the prisoner brought me this lathe; I received information, and gave him in charge - he seemed anxious to go away; I am certain of his person; he escaped from the officer; he gave the name of Clark, and said he brought it from his master.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner, at his mother's, on the 20th, he said he heard I had been looking after him.

Prisoner's Defence. I told the officer I had it from the prosecutor's son; whom I met in Red Lion-street, and he asked me to go and pawn it, and say it was my master's; he stood on the other side of the way, and beckoned me, when I was detained - I went over to him.

THOMAS HARRISON
. He gave this account on the 21st, the day he was committed; and the prosecutor's son said he had not seen the prisoner for six weeks; I knew the prisoner before; I went two or three times before I could find him; when I at first took him, he said he did not know the prosecutor's son.

JAMES ASTON
. My son had left me, and I told the officer to take him, as I had some suspicion of him.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Months .

764.
EDWARD BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of February , 3 shirts, value 1s.; 2 jackets, value 2s. 6d.; 1 pair of stockings, value 3d.; 3 pairs of trousers, value 1s.; 1 comforter, value 3d.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d., and 2 pairs of drawers, value 1s. , the goods of
Alexander Atkinson
.

JOHN GIBSON
. I keep a lodging-house, at Wapping. Atkinson lodged with me, and is gone to sea. The prisoner brought me a note, as from him, requesting I would deliver these clothes to him; I gave these articles to him; the prosecutor came for them himself, two days after; I said I had given them to the prisoner.

ELIZABETH KERSHAW
. I took the prisoner, and found some of the property on him; he said it was done, and could not be helped, he might as well die as be starved.
Prisoner's Defence. I went on board a ship, and Atkinson gave me the note - he said he meant to give himself up as a deserter from the Tribune frigate.

ELIZABETH KERSHAW
. He stated this before the Magistrate, and Atkinson denied it.
NOT GUILTY .

765.
HANNAH BLAKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of February , 1 shirt, value 1s. 6d.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 1s. 6d.; 1 cravat, value 9d., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
William Staines
.

WILLIAM STAINES. On the 21st of February, about eight o'clock in the morning, I was at the Nag's Head public-house, Hart-street, Covent-garden
. I called for a pipe - I had this property in a bundle; the prisoner came and sat opposite to me; she came in and out two or three times, with a man named Roberts; they had a pint of beer and a quartern of gin; she told the people in the tap-room, she had just come out of the House of Correction - I missed her and my bundle; I said to the man who came with her,"My bundle is gone;" he drank the beer and gin, and said he would go with me round the market, and see for her - we went, and could not find her; we returned to the house- I asked the man for his and her name and address, and sat down to write them, but the servant-girl brought this prisoner in, and said she met her coming out of a gin-shop- the prisoner said she had sold my things.

JOSEPH METCALF
. I am an officer. I was fetched to the house about half-past ten o'clock in the morning; Staines produced this handkerchief, which he said had contained the property, and that the prisoner had given it to him.
Prisoner's Defence. I had just come out of confinement, and had no place to go to; through my husband forsaking me.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

766.
JOHN HICKMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 1 coat, value 10s., the goods of
James Goodale
; and that he, (the prisoner,) before the commission of the said felony, (to wit,) on the 4th day of December, in the fourth year of his Majesty's reign, by the name of
John Asbury
, was convicted of felony .

JAMES GOODALE. On the night of the 4th of February, about nine o'clock, I left my horse and gig in the care of a young man, while I went to a house opposite Compton-street
- in about two minutes I heard a rattle - I ran out, and saw some person with my coat, which I had left in the gig.

JAMES PROTHEROE
. I saw the gig at the door of the King's Arms; I saw the prisoner go and take the coat - I followed and took him - I saw him drop it.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am an officer. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction - it is signed by Mr. Shelton, I know the prisoner to be the person named therein.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not at first identify me as John Groves? A. I mistook the name; Groves was connected with him - I knew him the moment I saw him, and said"Your name is Groves;" but on referring to my book, I found his name was Asbury.
The certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, was here put in and read.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Life .

767.
THOMAS LAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 2 sheets, value 20s., the goods of
William Snowley
; and 1 Prayer-book, value 1s., and 1 handkerchief, value 4d. , the goods of
Mary Quick
.

FANNY SNOWLEY
. I am the wife of William Snowley; he keeps the Bell and Mackarel, in Mile End-road
. The prisoner had lodged there three nights - these sheets did not belong to his bed.

MARY QUICK
. I am servant at this house. I lost my my Prayer-book and handkerchief from my box which was in my bed-room.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I am an officer. About ten o'clock in the morning of the 25th of February, I saw the prisoner go into a shop at Shadwell, and come out with a bundle; I followed and took him - I asked what he had got; he said two sheets, which he had brought from Dover; that he brought them from Jamaica; they were tied in this handkerchief, and the Prayer-book was in his hat.

JOSEPH GALLOWAY
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner to Greenwich where he said he had lodged. I found it was false; he then said I had had a deal of trouble, and he would tell me - that he took them from the Bell and Mackarel.
Prisoner's Defence. I have been twenty-two years in his Majesty's service, and was in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 56.
Confined Two Months .

768.
DENNIS CREAMER
and BRIDGET (HIS WIFE )
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , 1 ham, value 7s. the goods of
John Taylor
.

The prosecutor's name being John Taylor Smith, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED .

769.
WILLIAM OLIFF
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 1 sack, value 1s. 6d., and three pecks of beans and oats, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Adamson
.
WILLIAM ADAMSON. I am a market-gardener . The prisoner was in my employ, and had the care of my corn; this sack has my initials on it, and is mine - he has a wife and three children.

THOMAS SKITTERELL
. I am a watchman to Mr. Adamson. On Sunday evening I saw this sack in the stable; prisoner was there, and said, "I am going to Stamford-hill; I shall go out the back way; don't take any notice of it." I saw him go out towards Clapton; I followed him, and found him with this sack and corn, which I believe to be master's.

ROBERT BROWN
. I took the prisoner, with the sack and corn; he said it was the first time.
Prisoner. I am very sorry for it.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Two Months .

770.
SARAH LANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of February , 1 shawl, value 7s. , the goods of
Sarah Nicholas
, and
Simon Latter
.

JAMES HARRIS
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 23d of February, at ten o'clock at night, the prisoner came to pawn this shawl for 4s.; 1 suspected it was stolen, and asked where she had got it; she said she had just bought it at Messrs. Nichols for 6s.; but as there was a ticket marked 16s. 6d. on it, I detained her.

GEORGE WHIPPLE
. I am apprentice to Sarah Nichols and Simon Latter, pawnbrokers
, Ratcliffe
; this shawl is theirs, and was safe between five and six o'clock that evening; I did not miss it till Mr. Harris came.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .

771.
WILLIAM JOHNSTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of February , 6 lbs. weight of beef, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Smellie
.

THOMAS SMELLIE. I am a butcher , and live at Shadwell. I was in my shop at ten o'clock at night, on the 23d of February, and saw the prisoner take this beef from my window, just inside the shop; I called the watchman, and gave him in charge directly.

EVAN THOMAS
. I am a watchman. I was called, and took the prisoner and beef.

THOMAS SLACK
. I am headborough. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house; I found 9 1/2d on him.
Prisoner. I leave it to the mercy of the court.
GUILTY . Aged 53.
Transported for Seven Years .

772.
HENRY DENHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of February , 2 curtains, value 5s.; 1 counterpane, value 5s.; 2 blankets, value 8s.; 2 sheets, value 6s., and 2 pillows, value 6s. , the goods of
Ann Atlee
, widow .

ANN ATLEE. I live in Turnmill-street. The prisonerlodged with me for nine days; on the 2d of February he came and gave my child a book, and said he should work at home next week - I said the child could not read, and told him I wanted a flat iron: he fetched me down two from his room; he and his wife left that night - they took the key, and never returned; I broke the door open on Monday, and missed all this property, none of which has been found.

JOHN BALLARD
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner at the Horns, Kennington; I told him the charge - he said"I surrender myself to you, in order to exonerate the girl," alluding to a girl I had taken before - I found some money on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I can only deny it - the young woman I lived with took the room; the things were all safe when I left - I said I would exonerate the girl, because she left two hours before me, but I did not take the things; the door is always open, and there are several lodgers - I locked the door, and left the key in it when I left; I cannot recover my character, and if I am transported it will be a pleasure to me - but declare I am innocent.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

773.
GEORGE RIGGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 2 shillings , the monies of
Thomas Groves
.
MR. CHURCHILL conducted the prosecution.

HENRY DEWDNEY
. I am clerk to Thomas Groves. The prisoner was in his service; on the 18th of February I gave him 10s., with a written order to get some nails - I told him to bring a bill of them; he returned with this bill, which amounts to 8s. 8d. - he brought me 1s. 4d; I told him one item was much overcharged; and on Wednesday morning, as he was going by the shop, I desired him to call and get it corrected - Mr. Adams sent the bill back.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where had you sent him? A. To Messrs. Adams and Morris; I think I mentioned the mistake to him on the 18th - he staid with us till Thursday morning, when he was taken.

WILLIAM SALKELD ADAMS
. I am shopman to Morris and Adams. On the 18th of February the prisoner came with an order; I sent the goods with this bill - it amounted to 6s. 8d., but since it left our shop a figure of 2s. has been added to an item of 11d., and the 6s. at the bottom is altered to 8s.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you enter it in your book? A. Yes, it is 6s. 8d. there - I looked at the entry yesterday; I am certain of it without referring to the book.
COURT. Q. Is the bill now in the state the prisoner brought it to you? A. It is.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When he returned did he not tell you he had made a mistake? A. He gave the bill to Mr. Adams, and said it was a mistake; Mr. Adams called me and said it was a mistake of mine - I said it was not; the prisoner wished me to write a note, and give him the bill back, but I would not and kept it, saying there was a gross imposition some where.
Q. Was not your deposition copied three time? A. The clerk made so many mistakes, the Magistrate said he would have them copied again, or they could not be read.
COURT. Q. Are you quite sure the alterations in the bill are not your making? A. I am.
The prisoner put in a written defence, declaring his innocence.

HENRY SPICER
. I took the prisoner in charge - I remember the mistakes being made in Adam's deposition; it was taken by a new clerk - the Magistrate had them copied again.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

774.
ELIZABETH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January , 1 bolster, value 3s.; 1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 sheet value 4s., and 1 flat-iron, value 1s. the goods of
Sarah Conlan
.
SARAH CONLAN. I am a widow . The prisoner lodged at my house with a man; I missed these things.

STEPHEN STEVENS
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned a pillow, sheet and flat-iron with me at different times.

RICHARD BARBER
. I have a bolster, pawned by the prisoner, on the 15th of December.

CHARLES GEORGE VINCENT
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner - she said she did it through distress; I found the duplicate on her.
The prisoner pleaded poverty, and received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 49.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Two Months .
SEVENTH DAY. THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 28.
Second London Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

775.
JAMES CARROLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January , 1 boot, value 4s. , the goods of
Lucy Pendrill
.

LUCY PENDRILL. I am a widow , and live in Angel-street, St. Martin's-le-grand
. On the 31st of January my two boys were playing in my shop - one of them called Stop thief! and the prisoner was brought back with this boot.

GEORGE PENDRILL
. I was in my mother's shop, and saw the prisoner come in and take a boot off the shelf - I called Stop thief! he dropped it, and ran away; I am sure he is the man.

HEZEKIAH WILMER
. About seven o'clock on the 31st of January, I saw the prisoner at the corner of this window, and soon after heard a cry of Stop thief! I ran back, and took the prisoner, who was running from the shop; the boy said he had taken the boot.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

776.
BENJAMIN NATHAN
and
THOMAS FELL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of February , 24 1/2lbs. of cheese, value 15s. , the goods of
Isaac Shaw
.

ROBERT WILLAVIZE
. I am shopman to Mr. Isaac Shaw, a cheesemonger , of Gracechurch-street
. I did not miss this cheese till the officer brought it in on the 21st of February - I knew it to be Mr. Shaw's, by a cross on it, and a piece of tin was nailed on it; I doubt whether it had been sold; a lady was looking at it on the Saturday - she objected to it on account of its being bored so many times.

Cross-examined by MR. J. ALLEY. Q. Do you know who made the cross on it? A. My father, in the country- it is a common cross; I swear to it by a tin tack on it, where the tin was; it stood at the door, and was marked 7 1/2d. - I know nothing of the prisoner.

CHARLES THOROGOOD
. I am an officer.
